for headless it is recommended you have big robust marketing org with multichannel strategy.

unless you have that it is shooting sparrow with a cannon.

text: We use contentful for our website (<http://project-a.com|project-a.com>) - but it's not really set up that well for blogging yet (I'm pushing for our dev team to fix this). By default, there's a really bare-bones rich text editor.

elements.text: We use contentful for our website (
project-a.com
) - but it's not really set up that well for blogging yet (I'm pushing for our dev team to fix this). By default, there's a really bare-bones rich text editor.

text: I can ask our devs/product team how the migration experience was (actually, I wanted to blog about the process but it got pushed down in priority). We migrated from kirby BTW.

elements.text: I can ask our devs/product team how the migration experience was (actually, I wanted to blog about the process but it got pushed down in priority). We migrated from kirby BTW.

text: <@UUVC9HJTE> I'm looking for a fast website that I can update myself with a CMS (currently we have a custom React site and a developer who I have to work with to update even a sentence on the site)

elements.text: I'm looking for a fast website that I can update myself with a CMS (currently we have a custom React site and a developer who I have to work with to update even a sentence on the site)

text: I'm also worried that contentful is overkill for our purposes <@U0182FHDVPW> so that's good to know

elements.text: I'm also worried that contentful is overkill for our purposes
so that's good to know

text: I highly recommend Hubspot CMS + development on top HS. It works just good enough and with great FE + design team you can have a design system that allows you to do VERY fast iterations and changes to your website.

elements.text: I highly recommend Hubspot CMS + development on top HS. It works just good enough and with great FE + design team you can have a design system that allows you to do VERY fast iterations and changes to your website.

text: Hey everyone! I'm in the process of putting together a blog post and curious if anyone here has any general tips on how to develop a brand strategy (things that have worked long-term, times you've had to pivot the strategy, etc.)? If so, I'd love to hear about your experiences and any insights you could share!

elements.text: Hey everyone! I'm in the process of putting together a blog post and curious if anyone here has any general tips on how to develop a brand strategy (things that have worked long-term, times you've had to pivot the strategy, etc.)? If so, I'd love to hear about your experiences and any insights you could share!

text: Hello team! *What company have you seen do a really good job of helping you learn something?* Not so much massive learning platforms like Masterclass; more like Noom, The Nudge, NYT Cooking, etc. This content could be webinars, bite-sized content, email courses, etc. Think outside the box! TY!

elements.text: Hello team!
What company have you seen do a really good job of helping you learn something?

Not so much massive learning platforms like Masterclass; more like Noom, The Nudge, NYT Cooking, etc. This content could be webinars, bite-sized content, email courses, etc. Think outside the box! TY!

text: I'd have to say <https://tinylittlebusinesses.com/|Tiny Little Businesses> and their newsletter. :slightly_smiling_face:  Top 3 of my marketing blogs out there.

elements.text: I'd have to say
Tiny Little Businesses
and their newsletter.
Top 3 of my marketing blogs out there.

text: Does Duolingo count for learning new languages?

text: Bon Appetit’s Basically publication does a great job of teaching via their recipes. This one with step-by-step GIFs is a good example: <https://www.bonappetit.com/recipe/no-fail-roast-chicken-with-lemon-and-garlic>

text.text: *For B2B brands: Which term do you prefer?*

elements.text: Created by <@URB31QKM4> with /poll

text: I think these are totally different. A guide, to me, indicates that there will be steps involved, or things to check off, or a journey to move through. A whitepaper is thought leadership. And an ebook is more informational and probably design-heavy.

elements.text: I think these are totally different. A guide, to me, indicates that there will be steps involved, or things to check off, or a journey to move through. A whitepaper is thought leadership. And an ebook is more informational and probably design-heavy.

text:
+1 to what Deedi said. I also think these have  different jobs
• A whitepaper assures the person picking up the bill that the solution will do what the fancy marketing copy promises
• An ebook assures the manager / support roles that your team is thoughtful, smart and there is good theory behind whatever your company does
• A guide teaches the doer how to do the thing

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

elements.text: +1 to what Deedi said. I also think these have  different jobs

An ebook assures the manager / support roles that your team is thoughtful, smart and there is good theory behind whatever your company does
A guide teaches the doer how to do the thing
